content:
No, the U.S. government cannot use the information collected by the Census Bureau to target specific communities, including for immigration enforcement. The Census Bureau is required by law to protect the privacy of individuals who participate in the census, and information collected through the census cannot be shared with any other government agency, law enforcement or private organization.

The Census Bureau is bound by Title 13 of the U.S. Code to keep all information collected confidential and to use it only for statistical purposes, such as the allocation of federal funding and representation in government. Any Census Bureau employee who violates these provisions can be fined or imprisoned.

Moreover, the Census Bureau takes extensive measures to ensure the privacy and confidentiality of respondents’ information, such as conducting data validation and accuracy checks, and conducting comprehensive quality control procedures.

Therefore, participating in the census is safe and confidential, and the information provided cannot be used against individuals or their families in any manner by any government agency.
